description: Swayambhunath is an ancient religious architecture situated atop a hill in the valley. According to Swayambhu Purana, the entire valley was an enormous lake out of which the valley came to be known as Swayambhu, meaning self-created. It is probably the most sacred among Buddhist pilgrimage sites and also revered by Hindus. The complex consists of a stupa, shrines, and temples, some dating back to the Licchavi period. The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on, looking in all four directions.
fun_fact: It is also known as Monkey Temple for the living of holy monkeys, which are considered holy as they are the head lice of Manjushri, the Bodhisattva of wisdom and learning.

condition.status: The Swayambhunath complex suffered damage in the April 2015 earthquake.

historical_events.date: about the beginning of the fifth century CE

historical_events.event: Work done indicated by a damaged stone inscription
Visited by a notable figure who developed a temple on the hill

description: Swayambhunath is an ancient religious complex atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple. The Tibetan name for the site means 'Sublime Trees' for the many varieties of trees found on the hill. Swayambhunath is the major pilgrimage site for Buddhist Newars and second most important place after Boudhanath for Tibetan Buddhists. Swayambhunath, is among the oldest religious sites in Nepal. According to the Gopālarājavaṃśāvalī Swayambhunath was founded by the great-grandfather of King Mānadeva (464 -505 CE), King Vṛsadeva, about the beginning of the 5th century CE. This seems to be confirmed by a damaged stone inscription found at the site, which indicates that King Mānadeva ordered work done in 640 CE. The stupa was completely renovated in May 2010, its first major renovation since 1921 and its 15th in the nearly 1,500 years since it was built. However, the stupa faced many damages in the earthquake 2015.

historical_events.event_description: Swayambhunath was founded by King Vṛsadeva, the great-grandfather of King Mānadeva.
King Mānadeva ordered work done at the site.
The stupa was completely renovated, its first major renovation since 1921 and its 15th in the nearly 1,500 years since it was built.
The stupa faced many damages in the earthquake.
